pred:
**Youngest Person to Reach South Pole Solo: Scott Sears Completes 702-Mile Trek**

Scott Sears, a 27-year-old lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles, has become the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo and unsupported. He completed his 702-mile trek on Christmas Day, more than 12 days ahead of schedule. Sears, who is the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, pulled a sled and supplies for 38 days through extreme weather conditions, including 150mph winds and temperatures of -50c.

The journey was not without its challenges, with Sears describing hitting a wall on Christmas Eve, just 38km from the pole. However, he persevered and reached the pole the following day, saying he was "absolutely chuffed to pieces".

Sears' feat has raised over £33,500 for the Gurkha Welfare Trust to help rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, which were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake. He has also been praised by Andy Murray's mother, Judy, who tweeted congratulations on his achievement.

Sears' trek was a remarkable achievement, requiring over two years of planning and training. He faced numerous challenges, including navigating crevasse fields and glaciers, and traveling alone without a teammate to stop him from falling.

After completing his journey, Sears said he was looking forward to a well-deserved rest, including a shower and a meal. He acknowledged that it would take a few weeks for the experience to sink in, given his six weeks of isolation in a tent.assistant

answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Sears' message from Andy Murray's mom once he arrived at his destination: "Well done Scott Sears." If Guinness confirms Sears' feat, he'll be three years younger than the previous record-holder, per the Telegraph. (Prince Harry drank champagne out of a prosthetic leg when he arrived at the South Pole.)

A convicted murderer, Michael David Elliot, 40, escaped from the Ionia Correctional Facility in Michigan on Sunday evening. He was serving five life sentences for four murders and an armed robbery that occurred in 1993. Elliot was last seen wearing a blue and orange state prison uniform, but was later spotted in black pants, a white t-shirt, white tennis shoes, and a white beanie cap.

After escaping, Elliot carjacked a woman using a box cutter and held her hostage during a 100-mile drive to Elkhart County. The woman escaped at a gas station by asking for a cup of water and locking herself in the bathroom. Elliot fled in the victim's car, a red Jeep Liberty, which was later found in Shipshewana, Indiana.

A manhunt was launched, and authorities searched the area, including door-to-door canvassing and a lockdown of Westview Schools. However, the search was suspended, and it is unclear if Elliot is still in the area or has traveled elsewhere.

Elliot was arrested on Monday evening in LaPorte County, Indiana, after a short chase. He was found to have stolen four vehicles during his 24-hour run from the law. He is being held without bond on felony car theft and resisting charges.

The Michigan Department of Corrections Director, Dan Heyns, stated that Elliot was dressed in a white kitchen uniform, which may have helped him evade security cameras and fencing. An investigation is underway to determine how Elliot obtained the uniform and how he escaped.

Governor Rick Snyder thanked law enforcement agencies for their swift apprehension of Elliot and promised a thorough review of the incident to prevent future escapes. Elliot maintains his innocence and has filed a motion for release, citing new evidence in his case.assistant

pred:
**In Other Words Bookstore Cuts Ties with Portlandia**

The In Other Words bookstore in Portland, Oregon, has announced that it will no longer allow the TV show Portlandia to film at its location. The decision comes after a series of incidents, including a recent filming that left the store in disarray and staff mistreated. The bookstore's community also took issue with the show's portrayal of feminism and its lack of representation of people of color.

According to the bookstore, the show's filming has had a negative impact on the neighborhood and the city as a whole. The bookstore has received a small flat fee for each episode filmed at its location, but this does not cover the profits lost due to the store's closure during filming. Additionally, the show's popularity has led to an influx of tourists and fans who come to take selfies outside the store, but do not support the bookstore's mission or contribute to its financial sustainability.

The bookstore also criticized the show's portrayal of trans individuals, calling it "trans-antagonistic and trans-misogynist." The show's use of jokes about trans women, including a character played by Fred Armisen, was deemed "lazy, reactionary, and actively harmful."

Furthermore, the bookstore highlighted the show's lack of representation of people of color, particularly Black people, despite being set in a city with a history of racism and white supremacy. The show's production crew even asked the bookstore to remove a Black Lives Matter sign from its window during filming.

The bookstore's decision to cut ties with Portlandia was made by its community, and the current board, staff, and volunteers stand behind the decision. The bookstore is now seeking support from the community to continue serving as a hub for Portland's social justice community.assistant

The California State Auditor's Office has released a report highlighting several instances of improper governmental activities and employee misconduct across various state agencies. The report includes seven examples of investigations that substantiated improper governmental activities, including misuse of state time, inaccurate attendance records, economically wasteful activities, and misuse of government property.

The report found that four employees at several agencies misused state time, resulting in a loss of approximately $160,000. Two employees at California State University, Fresno, engaged in egregious time and attendance abuse, failing to account for over 5,100 hours of work and costing the state over $111,000. An employee at the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, Kern Valley State Prison, misused state time by regularly leaving work early, resulting in a loss of nearly $9,000.

The report also highlighted instances of nepotism, bad-faith hires, improper promotions, and other misconduct by executive management within two state entities. Additionally, the report found that a director of nursing at a Southern California prison reassigned a licensed vocational nurse to a position for which she was overqualified, resulting in a loss of nearly $30,000.

In another instance, a California Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) employee slept thousands of hours on the job since 2014, resulting in a loss of over $40,000. The employee's supervisors were aware of the issue but underestimated the amount of time she was sleeping on the job and did not properly follow disciplinary procedures.

The report also found that a high-ranking Cal Fire chief had two state employees build an addition to a state-owned house he rented during their work hours, without permission. The addition had plumbing, electrical, and sewer connections and was decorated as a tiki room.

The California State Auditor's Office investigated 1,481 instances of alleged improper governmental activities in the past year and issued nonpublic reports regarding nepotism, bad-faith hires, improper promotions, and other misconduct by executive management within two state entities. pred:
Egypt is facing its worst crisis since President Mohamed Mursi took office six months ago. The crisis began when Mursi issued a decree on November 22 that gave him wide powers and shielded his decisions from judicial review. The opposition, led by the National Salvation Front, has been protesting against the decree and the draft constitution written by an Islamist-led assembly.

On Wednesday, Islamist supporters of Mursi clashed with opposition protesters outside the presidential palace, with both sides throwing stones and petrol bombs. Riot police deployed to try to stop the confrontations, but were unable to halt the fighting. Medical sources reported that 23 people were wounded in the clashes.

Vice President Mahmoud Mekky attempted to calm the crisis by proposing amendments to the disputed articles in the constitution. He said that a written agreement could be submitted to the next parliament, to be elected after a referendum on the constitution on December 15.

The United States has called for dialogue on the constitution, with Secretary of State Hillary Clinton saying that it should "respect the rights of all citizens." The opposition has accused Mursi of creating a new autocracy and has demanded that he retract the decree and defer the referendum.

The crisis has spread to other cities, with offices of the Muslim Brotherhood's political party in Ismailia and Suez being torched. Prime Minister Hisham Kandil has called for calm and urged efforts to start a national dialogue.

Mursi has shown no sign of buckling under pressure, confident that the Islamists can win the referendum and parliamentary election to follow. The opposition has yet to generate a mass movement or grassroots base to challenge the Brotherhood.

The crisis has raised concerns about the stability of Egypt, a key ally of the United States and a state that has a peace deal with Israel. The army, which has traditionally been the muscle behind Egyptian presidents, has gone back to barracks, having apparently lost its appetite to intervene in politics.

The situation remains volatile, with both sides continuing to mobilize on the streets. The opposition has called for Mursi to retract the decree and defer the referendum, while Mursi has shown no sign of backing down. The crisis is likely to continue until a resolution is reached, with the fate of Egypt's political transition hanging in the balance.assistant

Though they called yesterday's protest a "last warning" to the president, Reuters notes that they have little real chance of stopping the vote, which Morsi is confident will approve the constitution.

Two former Nazi SS guards in their 90s have been indicted in Germany on charges of being accessories to murder while they worked at the Stutthof concentration camp during World War II. The men, aged 93 and 92, served as guards at the camp in Poland and are accused of being aware of the killings that took place there. The charges were filed under new German legal guidance that allows the prosecution of former Nazis who cannot be tied to specific killings.

The indictment was made possible through the assistance of Holocaust survivor Judith Meisel, who identified one of the guards, Johann Rehbogen, as a teenage SS officer who taunted her and other female prisoners at the camp. Meisel, 88, has been working with German prosecutors and FBI agents to bring justice to the few remaining Nazis who can be linked to World War II-era atrocities.

Meisel's testimony is crucial in challenging the defendants' denials of knowledge about the killings at the camp. She has described in detail the horrors she experienced at Stutthof, including witnessing camp inmates being killed by injections administered by doctors. Meisel's son, Michael Cohen, said his mother is still unsure how she would respond to the charges, but is interested in what comes next.

The trial is expected to commence next summer if the defendants are deemed healthy enough. Meisel could potentially take the stand as a witness or observe the proceedings. The charges are seen as a significant step towards justice for the survivors of Stutthof, where over 65,000 people died during the war.assistant

The documentary features interviews with prominent African-Americans, including poet Rita Dove, who praise Rosenwald's commitment to education and his role in fostering a sense of community and cooperation between Jews and African-Americans.

Ascoli's account highlights Rosenwald's devotion to family and community, as well as his desire to give back to the nation in which he prospered.

The documentary, directed by Aviva Kempner, is set to be released in mid-August and is expected to inspire a new generation of philanthropists and educators. Kempner hopes that the film will motivate others to continue Rosenwald's legacy of giving and community building. As Rosenwald himself said, "Not all of us can be Julius Rosenwald, but we can all do something."assistant

Rosenwald's philanthropic
answers: Julius Rosenwald is well known as the 20th-century American businessman who co-founded what we now call Sears. But a new documentary by Aviva Kempner explores Rosenwald's lesser-known role as a Jewish philanthropist who brought education to thousands of African-American children at a time when most had no schools to attend, reports the Root. "It's a wonderful story of cooperation between this philanthropist who did not have to care about black people, but who did, and who expended his considerable wealth in ensuring that they got their fair shake in America," civil rights leader Julian Bond explains in Rosenwald, out next month. It tells of Rosenwald's rise from the son of a peddler to a clothing manufacturing apprentice to CEO of the largest US retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Co., in 1908, reports the Times of Israel. It was around that time he began to see similarities between the treatment of blacks in America and pogroms against European Jews. When his rabbi became an NAACP leader, Rosenwald sponsored meetings. Soon after, he donated $25,000 to Alabama's Tuskegee University, led by Booker T. Washington, whose writings on racial equality and education had piqued his interest. Washington suggested the money go toward building six schools for black children, but Rosenwald contributed just a third of the funds and pushed the black and white communities to raise the rest. He went on to give $62 million to various causes, including the Rosenwald Fund, which created 5,300 schools in the South, attended by prominent African-Americans like Maya Angelou, George Wolfe, and Eugene Robinson. It "was the single-most important funding agency for African-American culture in the 20th century," poet Rita Dove says. More than 80 years after his death, Rosenwald still inspires. "Not all of us can be Julius Rosenwald," says Kempner, but "we can all do something."

Title: Taking Daughters to the C-Suite: A Call to Action for Women's Leadership

The Ms. Foundation's Take Our Daughters to Work Day, launched 20 years ago, has successfully demystified the workplace for girls. However, the mission has shifted from simply showing girls what an office looks like to encouraging them to become leaders. The current reality is that women hold only 3.6% of CEO positions, 14% of executive officer roles, and 16% of board director positions in Fortune 500 companies.

To address this disparity, it's time to take daughters to the C-suite, where corporate chiefs work. This requires more than just a single day of exposure; it demands proactive efforts to move women into leadership roles. Companies and schools must provide opportunities for girls to interact with successful women, understand the daily responsibilities and rewards of leadership, and receive sponsorship and support.

The Girl Scouts' recent study found that 80% of girls want to interact with successful women, but 60% have not been offered the opportunity. Introducing girls to female role models and highlighting their accomplishments can make a significant difference. Additionally, companies can provide sponsorship initiatives to identify and groom female talent.

Princeton University's efforts to increase female representation in leadership roles serve as a model. By proactively encouraging female students to apply for academic prizes, the university saw a significant increase in female Rhodes Scholars. Similarly, companies can provide sponsorship and support to help women advance in their careers.

The lack of women in leadership positions is not only a corporate issue but also a societal one, costing companies talent, hurting the country's competitiveness, and undermining ideals of fairness and social equality. It's time to take our daughters to the C-suite and provide them with the opportunities and support they need to become leaders.assistant

A federal class-action lawsuit has been filed against Spin Master, the manufacturer of the popular Hatchimals toy, alleging that the toy does not always hatch as promised. The lawsuit claims that millions of children and families were disappointed when the toy failed to hatch, and that the company's marketing campaign was deceptive and misleading.

The lawsuit was filed by Jodie Hejduk, a California mother who purchased a Hatchimal for her daughter's birthday. She claims that she and her daughter followed the instructions to hatch the toy, but it never emerged from its egg. Hejduk is seeking damages and a recall of the defective toys.

The lawsuit alleges that Spin Master knew that the hatching process was a key feature of the toy, but failed to ensure that the toys were functioning properly. The company's customer service was also criticized for being unresponsive and ineffective in resolving the issue.

The Hatchimals toy was a hot item during the holiday season, with many parents waiting in line for hours to purchase one. However, once the toys were opened, many children were disappointed to find that they did not hatch as promised. The toy's failure rate was reportedly high, with some parents paying up to seven times the retail price for a working toy.

Spin Master has denied the allegations, claiming that the company provided troubleshooting support and replacement products for those whose toys did not work as expected. However, the lawsuit alleges that the company's efforts were inadequate and that many consumers were left with defective toys.

The lawsuit seeks class certification, a recall of the defective toys, restitution with interest, and compensatory, statutory, and punitive damages for consumer law violations, unfair competition, false advertising, breach of warranty, and unjust enrichment. The case is ongoing, and a jury trial is expected to be held in the future.assistant

answers: Hatchimals, the hottest toys of the holiday season, laid an egg with many expectant kids Christmas morning when their furry hatchlings refused to come out of their shells. Now the manufacturer, Spin Master, is facing a class-action lawsuit from a California mom who alleges her child's egg was a dud. The lawsuit, filed by Jodie Hejduk of Bakersfield, Calif., on behalf of what the suit says could be millions of consumers, claims Spin Master ran "a bait-and-switch marketing scheme." Hatchimals are plush animals stuffed into plastic eggs that, when the egg is rubbed and cuddled for about half an hour, should begin to peck their way out. While Spin Master acknowledges some of the toys didn't work as intended, the company tells CNBC it "provided troubleshooting support and where required immediately made available replacement products." The toy cost about $50 in stores, but it was so popular it spawned internet bidding up to $350—only to leave many buyers disappointed. One customer wrote on Amazon.com that she "watched every YouTube video we could for help, but to no avail," the lawsuit says, per NBC News. Others complained that calling Spin Master had done no good because the company was "impossible to contact," or that when they got through they were told to open the egg themselves. Spin Master blames the toy's popularity, saying the company "experienced a higher than anticipated number of calls" over the holidays, and that the lawsuit's allegations are "not based on actual facts." But an attorney on the case tells Courthouse News that the toy's failure rate is "exceptionally high," and that the company knew the product wasn't ready for market. Hejduk's lawyer, Mark Geragos, tells ABC News his client was never offered a refund for her defective Hatchimal.
